description.summary: A flying Bigfoot-like creature with bat-like wings, reported once in 1994 near Mount St. Helens, Washington State following volcanic activity.
description.full: Batsquatch is a cryptid reported near Mount St. Helens, Washington in 1994. Described as a nine-foot tall humanoid with blue fur, yellow eyes, a wolf-like muzzle, and large bat-like wings, the creature allegedly flew past a vehicle driven by Brian Canfield shortly after volcanic activity. The creature represents a combination of traditional Bigfoot characteristics with the added feature of wings, similar to other winged humanoid cryptids. Despite the dramatic sighting, Batsquatch remains a one-time report with no subsequent confirmations.

etymology.origin: Portmanteau combining 'bat' and 'sasquatch' (the regional name for Bigfoot)

related_phenomena.name: Mothman
related_phenomena.description: Winged humanoid cryptid from West Virginia

features.description: Large bat-like wings capable of flight
Muscular humanoid body similar to Bigfoot

physical.morphology: Bipedal humanoid with ape-like musculature, bat-like wings, and wolf-like facial features. Stands approximately 9 feet tall.

abilities.description: Capable of powered flight using bat-like wings

range.description: Single sighting near Mount St. Helens, Washington State

origins.cultural_roots: Modern cryptid combining traditional Pacific Northwest Bigfoot lore with winged humanoid phenomena
origins.folklore_connections: Related to Bigfoot/Sasquatch traditions of the Pacific Northwest and winged humanoid reports

timeline.significance: Only documented sighting of Batsquatch near Mount St. Helens after volcanic eruption

history.modern_era: Batsquatch remains a curiosity in cryptozoology, representing a one-time report that has entered local folklore but lacks subsequent confirmation or supporting evidence.

notable.name: Brian Canfield Sighting
notable.description: Brian Canfield was driving near Mount St. Helens following a volcanic eruption when he reportedly observed a large, blue-furred, winged creature fly past his vehicle. The creature was described as approximately 9 feet tall with yellow eyes, a wolf-like muzzle, and large bat-like wings. The sighting occurred in the context of volcanic activity at Mount St. Helens.

factors: Unusual color (blue) inconsistent with known animals
credibility.notes: Single report with no corroboration or follow-up sightings. Timing with volcanic activity may suggest misidentification of debris or atmospheric phenomena.

paranormal.name: Volcanic Mutation
paranormal.description: Satirical theory that volcanic activity mutated a Bigfoot specimen

scientific.name: Misidentified Large Bird
scientific.description: Witness misidentified a large bird in post-eruption atmospheric conditions

skeptical.name: Hoax
skeptical.description: Fabricated story for attention or entertainment

skeptical.name: Misidentification
skeptical.description: Volcanic debris or atmospheric phenomena misinterpreted in stressful conditions

folklore.beliefs: Modern cryptid legend specific to Mount St. Helens area

indigenous.significance: No known indigenous traditions specific to winged Bigfoot
indigenous.respect_guidelines: Standard archaeological and ecological protocols for Mount St. Helens area

research.ongoing_studies: No active research; single historical sighting
